newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil president signs shipping bill.
newsitem.headline: Brazil president signs shipping bill.

text.p: Brazilian President Fernando Henrique Cardoso Wednesday signed a bill opening river and coastal shipping to foreign companies, officials in the Presidential Palace said.
The bill, passed last year by Congress, will come into effect once published in the government's Official Journal, possibly on Thursday.

The Transport Ministry said in a statement that the law would create the Brazilian Special Register, entitling national firms and foreign shipping companies with Brazilian bases to lower tax and employee contributions.

Companies which qualify under the register must employ Brazilian commanders and chief engineers on the vessels. Foreign companies without a base in Brazil can also operate but must employ crews that are two-thirds Brazilian.

Federal deputy Jose Carlos Aleluia, who drafted the law, said at a signing ceremony that the new regulations would reduce shipping costs in Brazil by 40 percent, the private Invest News agency reported.

The Transport Ministry concurred. "The benefits will be economic and environmental: reducing the cost of doing business in Brazil, reducing congestion on road networks and boosting the construction of vessels in national boatyards," it said.
